Dear Maria Madaj:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on January 30, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
• (2) An agency chief administrator is
administratively responsible for all the following
functions:
• (c) Not less than once annually, conduct
a written assessment and verify the
agency's compliance with the applicable
provisions of these rules.
Agency did not submit annual Chief Administrator assessment as required.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (3) The personnel record must contain both of
the following:
• (a) A written evaluation of a staff
member's performance within a
probationary period or not later than 6
months after the staff member assumes
his or her current responsibilities. After

the initial evaluation, a written evaluation
must be conducted every 12 months.
Three of three employee files reviewed did not have performance evaluation
completed within the past 12 months as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2/12/2024 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/1/2024
1/26/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/15/2023
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (4) An agency shall maintain an orientation and
training record for staff members.
Five of five new employee files reviewed did not have documentation the agency
maintained orientation for staff members as required.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not document preferred placement
specifications regarding SOGIE.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (2) The foster parent training plan must provide
for all the following:
• (b) Not less than 6 hours of training
annually for each licensee after the time
periods specified in subdivisions (a) of
this subrule.

One of three foster home files reviewed did not have documentation each
licensee completed 6 hours of annual training as required.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (1) Upon receipt of any information that relates
to possible noncompliance with any foster home
rule, the agency must do all the following:
• (a) Submit a special investigation record
to the department's licensing authority
within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
Two of four special investigations reviewed did not submit a special investigation
record to the department's licensing authority within 5 working days as required.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (a) The date the information was
received.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not have the report completed
within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (2) An agency shall maintain a file
documentation from the medical or dental
provider of all medical and dental care received
by a foster child.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation of all medical
and dental care received by a foster child.

CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (b) Notification of the child's parents, the
responsible agency, and guardian ad
litem as applicable within 24 hours of
knowledge of the following:
• (ii) A foster child's involvement with
law enforcement authorities.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation an incident
report was completed and required individuals were notified after a foster child's
involvement with law enforcement authorities.

• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's name prior to placement.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Recommend updating HR, licensing, foster care and independent living
checklists to ensure all requirements are being completed and reviewed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 2 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Special evaluation 2025SEC0000123 was initiated on 11/13/2024 regarding
allegations a licensed foster parent utilized corporal punishment as discipline. The
licensed foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency
policy. A CAP was implemented. Another special evaluation, 2025SEC0000146, was
initiated on 11/20/2024 regarding additional allegations of corporal punishment as

discipline. The licensed foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules
and agency policy. Revocation of the foster home license was initiated.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency interim inspection was completed on 2/12/2024 and the CAP was
approved on 4/1/2024. The agency was cited for 13 violations, 4 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 4, there was an improvement in individual incidents of
non-compliance within 2 of the violation areas and a slight increase in the number
of individual incidents in the other 2 areas. In 2023, 16 violations were established,
3 of which were repeated this year. All but one of the repeated violations remain
close to the same number of individual incidents on non-compliances. The agency
will need to establish additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to
ensure a reduction of incidents.
Special investigation 2024SIC0001277 was completed on 4/16/2024 and the CAP
was approved on 5/10/2024. The agency was found in non-compliance as the
agency did not make required face-to-face visits with an independent living youth
for over 3 months. The agency's CAP included conducting face-to-face visits no
later than the 21st of each month, adding calendar reminders and regularly
reviewing Book of Business. The agency complied with the CAP action steps and
no further concerns have been noted.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator assessment was not provided as required.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on review of the facility's budget
and the agency's financial audit.
Staff and Youth Interviews
An interview was conducted with two staff members via telephone. Staff reported
feeling frustrated a few months ago, however, things have settled down. Staff
reported feeling supported by supervision and coworkers. No concerns were
reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care service and licensing services. All files were stored securely
and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1: Licensed foster home did not respond to multiple attempts by
Agency Analyst to schedule a visit for DCWL audit.
Resolution: Licensing Program Manager conducted a home visit. Licensed foster
parent reported she is newly licensed and did not understand the importance of
responding timely. In addition, she worked late and didn't think to call since it was
after hours. A special evaluation was opened regarding the issue and the licensed
foster parent was found in noncompliance with licensing rules. A CAP was submitted
and has been completed.
Safety Alert #2: Licensed foster home did not respond to multiple attempts by
Agency Analyst to schedule a visit for DCWL audit.
Resolution: Agency licensing staff conducted a home visit and no noted concerns,
who reported she was out of state. A special evaluation was opened regarding the
issue and the licensed foster parent was found in compliance with licensing rules as
there was a miscommunication between the foster parent and Agency Analyst.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
